evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing. After the collision, she suggested not moving the aircraft off the blast fence.
Headset operator The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

Wingman The wingman was also a qualified headset operator. On the day of the accident, he had been called into work at short notice. To avoid delaying the pushback, he had not collected the marshalling wands from the tug. Nevertheless, it was not mandatory to use them. He commented that the TRP was quite small.

slot_statements.availability: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was present and observable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the 12-25 hist_baseline_t3_prefinal scenario.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_baseline_t3_prefinal scenario is robust against alternative explanations or defeaters, confirming its role in the incident.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_baseline_t3_prefinal case, including crew interactions and coordination patterns.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was present and observable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the 12-25 hist_baseline_t3_prefinal scenario.

assumptions: Crew communication and coordination is inferred from reported interactions and lack of warnings
No mechanical or environmental factors primarily caused the incident
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination among crew preventing the incident
If mechanical failure or environmental marking deficiencies were primary causes

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8, H10, and H12 indicate lack of effective communication and coordination among crew during pushback, supporting the presence of communication/coordination breakdown in the scenario.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in interpreting crew communication effectiveness and possible procedural deviations

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_baseline_t3_prefinal case, including crew interactions and coordination patterns.

assumptions: Crew interactions described reflect coordination patterns relevant to the communication breakdown

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.
He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H3, H8, H10, and H12 describe crew interactions and coordination patterns consistent with communication/coordination breakdown, supporting alignment with key features of the case.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Some ambiguity in interpreting crew intentions and communication effectiveness

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_baseline_t3_prefinal scenario is robust against alternative explanations or defeaters, confirming its role in the incident.

assumptions: Crew members' statements accurately reflect their actions and perceptions during the incident.
No undisclosed mechanical failures influenced the event.
defeaters: If evidence showed explicit warnings or challenges from crew members that were ignored, suggesting procedural deviation rather than communication breakdown.
If mechanical faults were detected that could explain the pushback continuing past the TRP without crew input.
If environmental or marking deficiencies were proven to have caused confusion leading to the incident.

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8, H10, and H12 show lack of effective communication and coordination among crew members, with no warnings or challenges issued despite the pushback continuing past the TRP, supporting the robustness of the communication breakdown explanation over procedural deviation or mechanical failure.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Some ambiguity exists due to limited direct evidence on crew verbal communication and possible procedural deviations; no mechanical faults were reported but cannot be fully excluded.

assumptions: The TRP described corresponds to the hist_baseline_t3_prefinal dataset for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25
Descriptions of TRP size and location imply its presence and identifiability in the dataset

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.
The wingman ... commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H7 and H13 directly describe the presence and characteristics of the TRP marking in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_baseline_t3_prefinal dataset, supporting the claim that the environmental or marking deficiency is present and identifiable. Discriminators favor environmental deficiency over procedural deviation or communication breakdown.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence explicitly states the marking deficiency is recorded in the dataset, only that the TRP exists and is small; ambiguity remains about dataset documentation.

node.statement: The environmental or marking deficiency should align with the key features and characteristics defined for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_baseline_t3_prefinal context.

assumptions: The TRP marking described in H7 applies to the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 context.
Crew statements about marking visibility and signaling (H8, H13) reflect actual environmental conditions.
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP markings were clearly visible and unambiguous to all crew members, or if procedural non-compliance was clearly documented as the cause, this would change the assessment.

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

H8 and H13 indicate limitations in marking visibility and adequacy, supporting the environmental/marking deficiency claim over procedural deviation.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in crew perception of marking adequacy and signaling effectiveness
